model_solution:
Step 1:  We are given a $2 \times 2$ matrix $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}.$
Step 2:  To compute the expression $\mathbf{A}^{27} + \mathbf{A}^{31} + \mathbf{A}^{40},$ we first need to calculate the powers of matrix $\mathbf{A}$.
Step 3:  We can start by calculating $\mathbf{A}^2$ using the definition of matrix multiplication.
Step 4:  \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 \cdot 3 + 7 \cdot (-1) & 3 \cdot 7 + 7 \cdot (-2) \\ (-1) \cdot 3 + (-2) \cdot (-1) & (-1) \cdot
Step 5:  \begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^3 &= \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 9 \\ -2 & -13 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 3 \cdot 1 + 7 \cdot (-2) & 3 \cdot 9 + 7 \cdot (-13) \\ (-1) \cdot 1 + (-2) \cdot (-2) & (-1) \cdot 9 + (-2) \cdot (-13) \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} -11 & -102 \\ 3 & 17 \end{pmatrix}.
\end{align*}
## Step 4: 
\[\mathbf{A}^4 = \mathbf{A}^2 \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 9 \\ -2 & -13 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 9 \\ -2 & -13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \cdot 1 + 9 \cdot (-2) & 1 \cdot 9 + 9 \cdot (-13) \\ (-2) \cdot 1 + (-13) \cdot (-2) & (-2) \cdot 9 + (-13) \cdot (-13) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -17 & -108 \\ 21 & 160 \end{pmatrix}.\]
